photo.description: Water Tower, Louisville, Kentucky.
photo.title: Water Tower

photo.description: Hit by the Second Cholera Pandemic in the 1830s-1840s, Louisville gained the grim moniker "graveyard of the West". In response, Kentucky created the Louisville Water company, first sewer company in the state. The company decided to make the pumping station and water tower in ornate Neo-Classical style, with the water tower being a single Dorian column supported by Corinthian columns. On top of the Corinthian columns stand ten pedestals containing Roman deities, the four seasons, and an Native hunter and dog. In 1890, the water tower was destroyed by a tornado, but was restored. The tower ceased operations after new reservoirs were created in 1909. Louisville, Kentucky
photo.title: Louisville Water Tower

photo.description: Taken by Kelley Dearing Smith, Louisville Water Company.
photo.title: Louisville Water Tower

photo.description: Located on the west side of Louisville, which would be considered a bad neighborhood, is the Old Forester Bourbon factory. The company that makes it is Brown-Forman Corp. and atop their building is their vintage water tower which has been made to look like their signature brand. This tower was in the news lately as this new design was unveiled in Sept. 2012 to reflect the change in the packaging. See the old version here: www.roadsideamerica.com/tip/10624
photo.tags: louisville ky kentucky watertower bourbon bottle worldslargest oldforester brownforman roadsideamerica bmok bmok2
photo.title: World's Largest Bourbon Bottle

photo.description: One of the statues on the white water tower at Zorn Pumping Station in Louisville, Kentucky. This was my favorite because she was very appropriately shading her eyes on this bright, sunny day.
photo.tags: louisville jeffersoncounty kentucky louisvillewatercompany zornpumpingstation watertower statue blue white sky
photo.title: Shading Her Eyes

photo.description: Looking ESE toward Zorn Ave. pumping station (the "Water Works"). Boats docked at Marine Sales and Service (right of center). Towboat "Matt S" (doc. # 907034) upbound. Ohio River mile 601. Louisville, Kentucky. Nov. 1987. File # 87k103. . "Matt S" was built in 1987 by Marine Builders, Utica, Indiana and originally operated by Marine Transportation, Utica. In 1992, the boat was sold to St. Jude and New Madrid Marine Service, Portageville, Missouri, and renamed "Capt. Jeff". . 35 mm Kodachrome. Plustek OpticFilm 7600i and Silverfast 8. Picture Window 6. JPEG quality 95.
photo.tags: river kentucky ohioriver louisville towboats towboat matts waterworks pumpingstation
photo.title: 87k103: Matt S upbound at Louisville Water Works

photo.description: Louisville Water hosts annual Adventures in Water Festival at the historic Louisville Water Tower.
photo.title: Adventures in Water

photo.description: For a century the Screen Tower, the smallest building serving River Pumping Stations Nos. 2 and 3, has stood in the Ohio River. It is mostly seen by people boating on the Ohio, who know it as the sign holder showing the high water mark of the 1937 Flood. However, it serves two other very important purposes: it is the intake point for water pumped from the Ohio River and it houses screens to prevent debris in the river water from being drawn into the pumps and causing great damage to the system. Construction of the tower began in 1910 and was completed in early 1913. It was ‘built to accommodate both of the (then) present stations (the original 1860 pumping station and Pumping Station No. 2) and have an outlet arranged for connection to a third pumping station at some future time.” Louisville Water Collection, 1982.0388
photo.title: Aerial View of River Pumping Stations & Screen Tower

photo.description: Among 8 Greek mythology statues on a water tower in Louisville, Kentucky, stands an American Indian and his dog or wolf. At Zorn Avenue and River Road in Louisville.
photo.tags: louisville jeffersoncounty kentucky louisvillewatercompany zornpumpingstation statue indian americanindian dog wolf sky blue
photo.title: A Man and His Dog

photo.description: Mother Nature is not always kind to the river pumping facilities. Large amounts of debris in the river can clog the screens. The arrow points to debris that was collecting around the screen tower during flooding in March of 1963, which clogged the intakes pipes and restricted the flow of water from the river. A “work boat crew” and diver were needed to remove the debris. Louisville Water Collection, 1983.0014
photo.title: Natural Hazards for the Screen Tower

photo.description: Looking SE (upstream) from Portland Canal near 22nd St.. Towboat "Billy Joe Boling" (doc. # 296549). Crewman waiting to get back on board. At right, sheetpile cells protect the bases of two electrical towers from damage by stray vessels during high water.. (Other cells along the canal are for mooring purposes, with posts (pins) for tying off.). Lift span of L&I Bridge in distance. Ohio River mile 606. Louisville, Kentucky. 18-Apr-1999. File # 99d047. . 6x9 cm color negative. scanned with Epson V500 flatbed scanner and Epson Scan software. edited with Picture Window 4
photo.tags: river ohioriver towboat towboats louisville kentucky portlandcanal libridge billyjoeboling
photo.title: 99d047: Billy Joe Boling

photo.description: The winter of 1977-'78 was especially bad for Louisville Water. That winter the Ohio River froze over, with one night having a recorded temperature of -20°. Suspended ice particles in the water froze on the intake screen, almost stopping the flow of water. Louisville Water Collection, 1982.0458
photo.title: Ice Clogs the Screens

photo.description: In February 2007, to celebrate their 150th anniversary, the American Insitute of Architects (AIA) named their America's Favorite Architecture list. For details about the methodology, see the topic posting, Methodology. For more information, see the AIA 150 website # 1: Empire State Building - New York City (William Lamb, Shreve, Lamb & Harmon) # 2: The White House - Washington, D.C. (James Hoban) # 3: Washington National Cathedral - Washington, D.C. (George F. Bodley and Henry Vaughan, FAIA) # 4: Thomas Jefferson Memorial - Washington D.C. (John Russell Pope, FAIA) # 5: Golden Gate Bridge - San Francisco (Irving F. Morrow and Gertrude C. Morrow) # 6: U.S. Capitol - Washington, D.C. (William Thornton, Benjamin Henry Latrobe, Charles Bulfinch, Thomas U. Walter FAIA, Montgomery C. Meigs) # 7: Lincoln Memorial - Washington, D.C. photo.description: Two Carrara marble angels at the rear of the church hold holy water bowls. The stained glass windows in Mutter Gottes Kirche were imported from the Royal Bavarian Establishment for Ecclesiastical Art, Mayer & Co., Munich, Bavaria. The windows along the sides of the church for the most part present Old Testament promises in the lower panels and their New Testament fulfillment in the upper panels. www.kenton.lib.ky.us/genealogy/history/covington/article.... Mother of God Church (Mutter Gottes Kirche) The German Catholics of Covington attended St. Mary Parish on 5th Street from the time of its founding. However, as their numbers increased, the need for a separate parish began apparent. In 1841, the Reverend Ferdinand Kuhr, a native of Eslohe, Prussia, was appointed to organize the Covington Germans into a new congregation. A temporary chapel was set up in a building on Scott Street in 1841. Mother of God was the second Catholic parish to be established in Northern Kentucky. In the spring of 1842, the congregation purchased a lot at the southwest corner of 6th and Washington. On this lot, a new church was constructed. The German population rapidly increased throughout the pre-Civil War era in Covington. A number of new daughter parishes were formed from the territory of Mother of God to meet these needs of these newcomers. Despite the development of new German parishes in the city, Mother of God congregation continued to flourish. In 1870, Father Kuhr and the parishioners began planning for the construction of a new Mother of God Church. The old church building was demolished and ground was broken for the new Italian Renaissance Revival structure. The new Mother of God Church sported a large portico supported by four Corinthian columns, two large towers and a cupola. mother-of-god.org/church.htm en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mother_of_God_Parish_(Covington,_KY)
photo.tags: january2009 muttergotteskirche motherofgod church catholic covington kentucky angel marble statue pillars pews stainedglass murals
photo.title: Interior of Mutter Gottes Kirche

photo.description: The Chicago Water Tower is a contributing property in the Old Chicago Water Tower District landmark district. It is located at 806 North Michigan Avenue along the Magnificent Mile shopping district in the Near North Side community area of Chicago, Illinois. Located adjacent to Loyola University Chicago's downtown campus, the Water Tower serves as one of the Chicago Office of Tourism's Official Visitor's Centers. The Chicago Water Tower is the second-oldest water tower in the United States, after the Louisville Water Tower in Louisville, Kentucky.
photo.tags: chicago illinois cook county city downtown water tower
photo.title: Water Tower Building

photo.description: The Chicago Water Tower is a contributing property in the Old Chicago Water Tower District landmark district. It is located at 806 North Michigan Avenue along the Magnificent Mile shopping district in the Near North Side community area of Chicago, Illinois. Located adjacent to Loyola University Chicago's downtown campus, the Water Tower serves as one of the Chicago Office of Tourism's Official Visitor's Centers. The Chicago Water Tower is the second-oldest water tower in the United States, after the Louisville Water Tower in Louisville, Kentucky. The tower, built in 1869 by architect William W. Boyington from yellowing Lemont limestone, is 154 feet (47 m) tall. Inside was a 138 foot (42 m) high standpipe to hold water. In addition to being used for firefighting, the pressure in the pipe could be regulated to control water surges in the area. The tower gained prominence after the Great Chicago Fire of 1871. While some incorrectly believe that the tower was the only building to survive the fire, a few other buildings in the burned district survived along with the tower. But the water tower was the only public building in the burned zone to survive, and is the only one of the surviving structures still standing. In the years since the fire, the tower has become a symbol of old Chicago and of the city's recovery from the fire. Oscar Wilde stated the Water Tower looked like "a castellated monstrosity with pepper boxes stuck all over it." In 1918, when Pine Street was widened, the plans were altered in order to give the Water Tower a featured location. The Water Tower's castle-like style inspired the design of many White Castle restaurant building ---- Above text from Wikipedia This is a composite of 35 frames.

photo.description: Surveying all he can see, Hermes sits atop Louisville's nineteenth century Water Tower. The Water Tower of Louisville and its water pump straddles the banks of the mighty Ohio River. It is proof that Louisville's water towers and pumps have flair, and have had it for a long time.

photo.description: Source : Wikipédia The Chicago Water Tower is a contributing property in the Old Chicago Water Tower District landmark district. It is located at 806 North Michigan Avenue along the Magnificent Mile shopping district in the Near North Side community area of Chicago, Illinois. Located adjacent to Loyola University Chicago's downtown campus, the Water Tower serves as one of the Chicago Office of Tourism's Official Visitor's Centers. The Chicago Water Tower is the second-oldest water tower in the United States, after the Louisville Water Tower in Louisville, Kentucky. History : The tower, built in 1869 by architect William W. Boyington from yellowing Joliet limestone, is 154 feet (47 m) tall. Inside was a 138 foot (42 m) high standpipe to hold water. In addition to being used for firefighting, the pressure in the pipe could be regulated to control water surges in the area. The tower gained prominence after the Great Chicago Fire of 1871. While some incorrectly believe that the tower was the only building to survive the fire, a few other buildings in the burned district survived along with the tower. But the water tower was the only public building in the burned zone to survive, and is the only one of the surviving structures still standing. In the years since the fire, the tower has become a symbol of old Chicago and of the city's recovery from the fire. In 1918, when Pine Street was widened, the plans were altered in order to give the Water Tower a featured location. The structure has not been universally admired. Oscar Wilde said it looked like "a castellated monstrosity with pepper boxes stuck all over it." The Water Tower's castle-like style inspired the design of many White Castle restaurant buildings. TheTower was named an American Water Landmark in 1969. In 2004, the tower was featured in the finale of The Amazing Race 6.
photo.title: Chicago (ILL) Near North Side, Magnificient Mile : Chigaco Water Tower, 1869.

photo.description: The Chicago Water Tower is a contributing property in the Old Chicago Water Tower District landmark district. It is located at 806 North Michigan Avenue along the Magnificent Mile shopping district in the Near North Side community area of Chicago, Illinois. Located adjacent to Loyola University Chicago's downtown campus, the Water Tower serves as one of the Chicago Office of Tourism's Official Visitor's Centers. The Chicago Water Tower is the second-oldest water tower in the United States, after the Louisville Water Tower in Louisville, Kentucky. From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

photo.description: Traveling north on the Ohio River we pass the Water Tower of Louisville, Kentucky (1856), it is the oldest ornamental water tower in the world, having been built before the more famous Chicago Water Tower. Both the actual water tower and its pumping station are on the National Register of Historic Places. As with the Fairmount Water Works of Philadelphia (designed 1812, built 1819-22), the industrial nature of its pumping station was disguised in the form of a Greek temple complex. The paddlewheel is made up of a central shaft and frame that holds the wooden planks called “buckets.” These planks are 24 feet long and are made of white oak, one of the hardest woods available. The wheel is 17 feet in diameter. Each end of the shaft is connected to a pitman arm which is connected to the engine. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louisville_Water_Tower

photo.description: This cross section of the Screen Tower was included in the 1912 Annual Report. It gives the tower’s dimensions and shows the inner workings of the tower. Four rectangular screens are in position between the two influent pipes from the river and the four going to the pumps. To clean the screens, they were pulled up by a motor driven hoist to the cleaning floor and then lowered back into position. The thick, concrete walls were designed to withstand the impact of debris floating down the river. Note the vertical lines at the bottom of the illustration. These indicate the spacing of the wooden pilings that were driven into the muddy river bed to help anchor the tower in place. Louisville Water Collection, 1912 Annual Report
photo.title: Measured Drawing of Screen Tower Showing Original Design

photo.description: at the water tower for the annual reggae fest.

Only the top of the Screen Tower could be seen at the height of the 1937 Flood; the river reached its highest crest ever - 57.1 feet. The water reached to the bottom of the windows. Even though the boilers were flooded and there was nearly five feet of water in the pumping stations, Louisville Water did not miss a day of pumping water into the reservoir. Louisville Water Collection
photo.title: Screen Tower During 1937 Flood

photo.description: May 3rd 1045 Conduit inundated by backwater from Green and Nolin Rivers. Minimum discharge was causing pressure to build and water to surge, resulting in spray. After coordination with Dam Safety and Water Management, the gates at the control tower were completely closed. A very rare occurrence. Tailwater Elevation – 443.30

photo.description: All the screens were rehabilitated in 1963 as part of the project to increase the river intake from the original four 48-inch pipes to two large 84-inch pipes. The added capacity was needed to accommodate the three new electric pumps added in 1961, increasing the River Pumping Stations' pumping capabilities from 230 million gallons per day (MGD) to 304 MGD. This photograph originally appeared in the June – July 1963 issue of Louisville Water’s newsletter, Facts Unfiltered, with the caption: “Here’s how the giant intake tunnels, shown near completion, were being tied into our River Station pumping plant screen tower. Holes had to be cut through 6-foot concrete walls. ‘Floor level’ in the photo is many feet below river surface, work proceeding behind a cofferdam holding back the water.” Louisville Water Collection, 1982.0378
photo.title: Rehabilitation of the Screens

photo.description: Inside the base of the Screen Tower with the traveling screens removed, revealing the open end of one of the old four 48-inch cast-iron intake pipes, leading from the screen tower to one of the pumps. Louisville Water Collection, 1982.0327
photo.title: 48-Inch Cast-Iron Intake Pipe
